title: Box launched from ramp - motion at maximum height

content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A box is pressed against a horizontal spring, compressing the spring from its relaxed length. The box is then released, and the spring launches the box horizontally along a track that ends in a ramp, as shown above. The box has enough speed to leave the ramp, and the box reaches a maximum vertical height above the floor. Assume there is negligible friction between the box and the track and air resistance is negligible.

<math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the spring constant of the spring.

<math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed.

<math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the box.

<math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (theta) is the angle of the ramp from the horizontal.

<math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the maximum height reached by the box.

The scenario is repeated using a stiffer spring with a spring constant that has a greater value for <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> than that of the original spring. The stiffer spring is compressed the same distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the same box is used.

(a) Indicate how using a stiffer spring would affect the maximum height reached by the box, and explain why without mathematically deriving a relation for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed.

The scenario is repeated using a stiffer spring with a spring constant that has a greater value for <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> than that of the original spring. The stiffer spring is compressed the same distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the same box is used.

(a) Indicate how using a stiffer spring would affect the maximum height reached by the box, and explain why without mathematically deriving a relation for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Students derive an equation for the maximum height, <math alttext="h equals, the fraction with numerator open parenthesis, the sine squared of theta, close parenthesis, times k, times x squared, and denominator 2 times M, times g, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>M</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, which may or may not be correct. Is this equation consistent with your claim in part (a)? Explain why or why not.

Two students are discussing the motion of the box when it is at its maximum height and make the following statements:
Student 1: The speed of the block at its maximum height is zero because the kinetic energy is a minimum at the top of the trajectory.
Student 2: Only the vertical component of the velocity is zero at the maximum height, because the vertical component of the acceleration is zero at the top of the trajectory.
(c) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(d) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”
(e) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(f) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”

(g) Consider the system consisting of the box and the spring, but not Earth. How does the energy of the system when the spring is fully compressed compare to the energy of the system at the moment immediately before the box hits the ground? Justify your answer.
(h) If the friction between the track and the box were not negligible, state one way in which the setup could be changed such that the maximum height of the box was the same as in the original setup.

The graph below shows the horizontal component of the displacement of the box as a function of time. The graph represents the entire time the box is in the air after the box is launched from the ramp at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal.

(i) How would the slope of the graph be different, if at all, if the ramp angle were larger than <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, but less than 90 degrees, and the height of the end of the ramp were the same? Justify your response.
